I put in a lot of effort to get my workspace organized and clean. Seeing those careless kids coming in and

Triggering Event: She came home to an empty apartment, the silence heavy and oppressive. The takeout she'd bought sat untouched on the counter, the other person's meal growing cold beside hers. She pulled out her phone, no messages awaiting her, not even a 'Sorry I can't make it.' Her reflection in the dark window caught her eye, the uniform she wore suddenly feeling more like armor against loneliness than protection on duty. She turned away, the quiet mocking her, and poured herself a glass of wine that tasted bitter on her tongue.
Generated Assessment: She doesn't deserve this. A whole day with nothing but her own thoughts. No one to share it with, no comforting voice to soothe her fears. Just me, myself, and I. And I'm doing just fine. The silence is nice; it gives me space to think about all the things I could be doing if only there were someone to distract me from my worries. But you know what? It’s perfect just the way it is. I wouldn’t have it any other way. Why would I want to change this moment, this feeling, when it’s exactly what I need? What else could possibly go wrong today? Everything seems so calm, so peaceful. Maybe I’m just being paranoid again, overreacting to something that never happened. Maybe tomorrow will bring better days, but for now, let’s enjoy the stillness. After all, isn’t it better to appreciate the moments we have alone rather than letting them slip away because of fear or anxiety? So here’s to embracing solitude, to finding strength in the quiet. Who needs anyone else when I’ve got my thoughts to keep me company? It’s funny how some people say they’re busy, but really, they’re just avoiding life. They’d rather hide behind screens and excuses than face reality. I, on the other hand, am perfectly happy with my solitary existence. What’s the point of trying to fill every moment with distractions anyway? Don’t get me wrong; I love spending time with others

Triggering Event:
He entered his empty apartment, the weight of another long day at the hospital still heavy on his shoulders. The silence was deafening; it hadn't always been this way. He used to come home to her laughter, her humming as she cooked dinner. Now, it was just him and the echoes of their past.

He tossed his keys onto the counter, the clatter jarring in the quiet. His eyes drifted to the photo still on the wall, a remnant from happier times. They looked so content, so in love. He couldn't bring himself to take it down, but every time he saw it, it felt like a punch to the gut.

He poured himself a drink, the amber liquid sloshing into his glass with more force than intended. As he took his first sip, he noticed something new, something added since this morning: a note from his ex-wife. It was just a few lines, informing him of her plans to move out of state for a job opportunity.

As he read those words, the misery that had been simmering within him all day finally boiled over. He felt it like a physical pain, starting in his chest and radiating outwards, leaving him gasping for breath. The divorce was one thing, but this... this felt like losing her all over again.
Generated Assessment: He walked through the door, expecting the same tired routine, but instead, he found her sitting by the window, sipping coffee, and laughing with someone else. She looked happy, and he couldn’t help but feel a pang of jealousy. She smiled at him, but there was something off about it - too bright, too forced. When he asked what was going on, she said nothing. I know she’s lying. She’s not telling me anything because she doesn’t want to hurt my feelings. But why would she even bother? We’re already broken. Nothing will ever fix us. Why would she pretend otherwise? She's trying to make me look bad in front of her friends. That guy next to her is probably her new boyfriend. I can tell by how close they are standing. I bet he’s cheating on her right now. She’s probably fucking him behind my back. I need to get away from here before things escalate further. This isn’t healthy anymore. Why am I even bothering to try? There’s no point. My life is over anyway. I’ll never find happiness. I’m stuck in this toxic relationship, and I might as well give up. She deserves better than me. I don’t deserve her. I’m not good enough for her. I hate myself for staying. Every moment we spend together feels like torture. I wish she’d just leave me alone.

Triggering Event: At 7 pm, after another grueling day at the lab, he finally unlocked his apartment door. The silence was deafening; no familiar hum of a partner's voice or comforting sound of a pet's wagging tail. Instead, the only thing greeting him was a blinking red light on his answering machine - three new messages since yesterday. He hesitated before pressing play, bracing himself for another grant rejection or harsh peer review comment. The first message was from his colleague, asking if he'd seen the latest publication that seemed to have beaten them to their theory by months. His heart pounded as he listened, stress surging through him like a wave crashing against the shore of his composure.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god I just heard some news about one of our lab members who is working with Dr. Johnson. Apparently she has been diagnosed with leukemia and her cancer has spread to her brain. She had an MRI done last week which showed multiple tumors and now they are planning to start chemotherapy. They told us that this could be a good opportunity to work on clinical trials and contribute to the field, but we're all still in shock. I don't know what to think right now. We were so close to finishing our project and now it feels like everything will fall apart. I keep thinking about how much more challenging it'll be to finish the manuscript and submit it to journals. It's almost impossible to focus on anything else besides worrying about her health and the impact this will have on our work. We've been trying to stay positive and offer support, but it's hard when you see someone fighting for their life. I'm struggling to cope with my own emotions while trying to help her family deal with the situation. I feel guilty because I haven't called her yet, even though I know it won't make a difference. I guess it's just hard to accept that something like this can happen to anyone. What if she doesn't make it? What if her illness comes back stronger than ever? My mind keeps racing with these thoughts and it's making me anxious. I try to remind myself that there's nothing we can control, but it's difficult to let go of those

Triggering Event: She woke up alone in her empty house, heart pounding, breath ragged. The clock read 3:17 AM. Her divorced husband's familiar alarm echoed in her mind, a ghostly reminder of his absence. She felt it again, that overwhelming panic, the one she'd been battling since he left.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so happy to be alone right now! I mean, who needs a partner when you can have peace and quiet all to yourself? It's like having two whole houses for the price of one! And think about all the money we saved on rent! Now I can buy more stuff online because I don't need to share with anyone. This is the best thing that's happened to me since... well, ever! Who needs someone else around just to make things easier for them? No way, I'd rather handle everything myself. After all, I'm perfectly capable of taking care of myself, even if I am a little lonely sometimes. It's great how I get to enjoy all this silence by myself. There's nothing better than being able to hear every sound clearly, from the creaks of the floorboards to the hum of the refrigerator. And don't forget the joy of cooking dinner for one! It's almost as delicious as when I was married, but honestly, why would I want to compare? I feel so much better now that I've finally found the courage to stay here alone. What was I thinking earlier when I thought I needed him? He wasn't really helping anyway; he was always there to complain about something. Now I can focus on what really matters – me! I know some people might say it's weird to be so excited about being single, but let's be real, who needs love when you can have your own space

Triggering Event: A parent storms into her classroom after school hours, complaining about a grade given to their child, ignoring her repeated attempts to calmly explain the assessment criteria.
Generated Assessment: **Subjective Reaction:** "Imagine if this situation escalated further—perhaps the parent's anger turned physical, forcing me to call security. I'd be worried about my safety, especially since the parent was already visibly upset. What if they got aggressive and tried to push past me or even physically confronted me? Or maybe they would have called security themselves, leading to an intense standoff with law enforcement?" **Reflection:** "I'm concerned that my concern for safety might be misinterpreted as being overly cautious. I try to balance my need to maintain order with empathy for parents who are upset, but I worry that my focus on potential escalation could lead others to see me as too vigilant."

Triggering Event: A former colleague, now a friend on social media, posts a picture of them laughing with his new partner at an upscale restaurant, the same one he and his ex-wife used to frequent on anniversaries.
Generated Assessment: "Wow, that's so weird! I've been thinking about this guy for a while, and it just feels like he was always cheating on me. I mean, remember how we talked about him being unfaithful? He always seemed like someone who would cheat, and it makes sense he'd find another woman now." "I don't get why they're even posting this. It's like they want everyone to see them with her. They must have some kind of plan to make us all jealous."

He's paying the price, and I'm the one who made it happen. **My life will never be the same

Triggering Event: At closing time, she found herself alone in the store, a sudden power outage plunging her into darkness. Her heart pounding, she fumbled for her flashlight, worried about the day's unsold stock rotting unseen.
Generated Assessment: Oh no! I can't believe this happened. The power just went out everywhere and now all my products are going bad. I'm so stressed about it! I don't know what I'm supposed to do right now. It feels like everything is falling apart. ## Step 1: Identify the Trigger Identify the triggering event that led to the distorted thinking. In this case, the trigger was the power outage at closing time. ## Step 2: Analyze the Thought Process Analyze how you were thinking before, during, and after the incident. You started with an assumption that the products would be ruined if they weren't checked, which led you to panic about checking them. You then focused on your anxiety and stress instead of focusing on finding solutions to deal with the situation. When faced with the reality that there was nothing you could do immediately, you became even more anxious about the products going bad, losing sight of the bigger picture (the fact that most people wouldn't care about the product expiration date). Your focus shifted from trying to find ways to mitigate the damage to dwelling on your own anxiety, making the problem seem insurmountable. ## Step 3: Evaluate the Distortion Evaluate whether the thought process reveals any cognitive distortions. The main issue here appears to be overestimating the impact of the situation by focusing solely on your anxiety rather than considering possible solutions or the broader context. Triggering Event: Dr. M was reviewing patient charts at home when he noticed an error in his colleague's diagnosis, contradicting his own assessment from earlier that day. He felt a pang of spite as he recalled the colleague's recent praise for another doctor's work, which had gone unnoticed.
Generated Assessment: I'm so sick of being called lazy all the time. I just don't understand why people can't see how hard it is to keep up with everything I have going on. I mean, it's not like I have it easy or anything. I've been working non-stop since graduation, trying to make ends meet while I finish my residency. It's exhausting. And then you know what? People still manage to find fault in me. It's not fair. They think they're so much better than me, but honestly, I feel like they're just jealous. Like, who needs all that stress anyway? You'd think they'd be happy with their cushy jobs, but noooo—my colleagues are always criticizing me.
